translation.ko: 우린 이 우주 계획을 다른 관점에서 보고 싶습니다

translation.en: We believe that we are actually producing values,
and we are producing values
at a faster rate than we are taking money out of the treasury.
translation.ko: 국고를 사용하는 것보다 더 빠르게 진행 중이죠

translation.en: [Kluger] Nixon had a choice to continue the program to go on to Mars.
The infrastructure for planetary exploration was in place.
translation.ko: 행성 탐험을 위한 기반 시설이 준비됐고

translation.en: The NASA personnel infrastructure that had gotten us to the Moon
translation.ko: 우리를 달로 이끈 나사의 인적 기반은

translation.en: was prepared to get us to Mars.
Mr. Speaker, the President of the United States!
[Nye] I gotta tell you, everybody,
this longing for the Apollo era is not well advised.
It's not coming back.
We're operating now not under the Kennedy doctrine,
but under the Nixon doctrine.
In reaching the Moon, we demonstrated
what miracles American technology is capable of achieving.
translation.ko: 미국 기술이 일궈 낼 수 있는 기적을 입증해 냈고

translation.en: And now the time has come to move more deliberately
translation.ko: 이제 이곳 지구에서 더욱 신중한 자세로

translation.en: toward making full use of that technology here on Earth.
translation.ko: 그 기술을 십분 활용할 때가 왔습니다

translation.en: [Nye] President Nixon and his advisors
felt that U.S. public interest in space exploration had waned.
translation.ko: 우주 탐험에 관한 미국 대중의 관심이 식었다고 생각했고

translation.en: It was a very expensive undertaking. Let's do something else.
translation.ko: 이 값비싼 사업 대신 다른 일을 하기로 했죠

translation.en: [newscaster] Sunday, April 12, 1981. Kennedy Space Center, Florida.
The Space Shuttle.
Fourteen stories high, 2,000 tons, poised on the pad for its maiden flight.
translation.ko: 14층 높이, 2천 톤 무게로 첫 비행을 준비 중입니다

translation.en: [Kluger] Nixon's goal was to contract America's space footprint.
translation.ko: 닉슨은 미국의 우주 영역을 축소하는 게 목표였어요

translation.en: To make getting to and from orbit routine, affordable,
and ultimately profitable.
But the Nixon doctrine,
the idea of monetizing and simplifying access to orbit,
translation.ko: 궤도로의 접근을 단순화해서 돈을 벌고자 한 발상은

translation.en: did not work.
[mission control] ...two, one, starting motor ignition and liftoff!
translation.ko: 둘, 하나 모터 점화 시작, 발사!

translation.en: Liftoff of Columbia!
The shuttle has cleared the tower.
Columbia, you're negative seats.
And liftoff.
Liftoff of the orbiter Challenger and the sixth flight of the Space Shuttle.
translation.ko: 챌린저호와 함께 여섯 번째로 우주 왕복선을 발사합니다

translation.en: [Kluger] What's been happening at NASA has been a very long term drift
in terms of the manned space program.
After we went to the Moon,
it was the carousel of shuttle flights around the Earth for 30-some years.
translation.ko: 30여 년간 왕복선이 지구 주변을 왔다 갔다 했고

translation.en: That was it.
[mission control] We have ignition and liftoff
of Atlantis and the Galileo spacecraft bound for Jupiter.
translation.ko: 아틀란티스호와 갈릴레오호가 목성을 향해 점화 및 발사됐습니다

translation.en: [CAPCOM] Roger roll, Atlantis.
[Dr. Kaku] The Space Shuttle can't reach deep space.
translation.ko: 우주 왕복선은 먼 우주에 도달할 수 없어요

translation.en: The Space Shuttle was only designed to go whizzing around the planet Earth.
translation.ko: 왕복선은 지구 주변을 맴돌게끔 제작됐을 뿐이고

translation.en: And so we began to realize that NASA lost its way.
translation.ko: 우린 나사가 방향성을 상실한 걸 깨닫기 시작했죠

translation.en: And liftoff of Space Shuttle Discovery
to complete NASA's constellation of tracking stations in the sky.
[Raj] I understand things are being done by NASA right now.
translation.ko: 지금 나사가 노력 중이란 건 알지만

translation.en: But I feel like after the '60s,
the acceleration of the program just declined to a sad point.
translation.ko: 계획의 가속도가 안타까울 정도로 느려진 듯해요

translation.en: [mission control] And liftoff of the Space Shuttle Endeavour.
[CAPCOM] Roger roll, Endeavour.
[deGrasse Tyson] We are no longer advancing a space frontier.
translation.ko: 우린 더는 우주를 개척하지 않고 있어요

translation.en: A space frontier is: how far have you gone lately?
Where are our farthest astronauts?
They're 250 miles above our head, driving around the block,
boldly going where hundreds have gone before.
translation.ko: 이미 몇백 명이 다닌 길을 뻔뻔하게 돌고 있는데

translation.en: That is not advancing space frontiers.
[Urban] Low Earth orbit is about putting stuff in space to look back down on Earth.
translation.ko: 지구 저궤도는 지구를 내려다볼 위성을 두는 곳인데

translation.en: It's about support for Earth industries.
The Space Shuttle sounds like this big exciting thing.
translation.ko: 우주 왕복선은 아주 거창한 것 같죠

translation.en: The Space Shuttle! We're exploring!
But actually what the Space Shuttle was was kind of a cargo delivery vehicle.
translation.ko: 그런데 우주 왕복선은 일종의 화물 운송 수단이었어요

translation.en: It would bring astronauts and equipment, back and forth from low Earth orbit.
translation.ko: 지구와 지구 저궤도를 오가며 우주인과 장비를 날랐죠

translation.en: [Kluger] The Shuttle drained NASA's resources.
It was a financial sinkhole, essentially, from 1975 up through 2011.
Any dreams of going to Mars during the Shuttle era were impossible
translation.ko: 왕복선 시대에 화성에 가는 건 불가능한 꿈이었어요

translation.en: because all of the money was going to the Shuttle.
[Josh] NASA is kind of at a holdup. We haven't gone places.
So don't go to space.
But what you can send to Mars are non-humans and non-living things,
translation.ko: 근데 인간이 아닌 무생물체를 화성에 보낼 순 있죠

translation.en: like robots.
[instructor] Before you leave this table, I need you to figure out what your robot's primary task is going to be.
translation.ko: 각자 로봇의 주요 과제를 파악하고 돌아가

translation.en: You can't just send all of them in there and have all four of them try and do the same task.
translation.ko: 네 대 모두 하나의 과제를 수행할 순 없잖아

translation.en: That's not going to be productive.
[Aurora] All right, guys, we got everything up here, so...
Is that everything?
-[Aurora] Yes, it is. -Can we get a picture?
[Jace] We do robotics at Space Camp
because robotics is a huge part of the space program.
translation.ko: 로봇 공학이 우주 계획의 막대한 부분이기 때문이죠

translation.en: Exploration done today isn't done by humans.
It's done by robots.
[Kluger] NASA's unmanned exploration of the solar system
is the great unappreciated crown jewel of the space agency.
[newscaster] It began here at the Kennedy Space Center, Florida.
translation.ko: 다시 한번 이곳 플로리다의 케네디 우주 센터에서

translation.en: Viking 1 and Viking 2 were readied for their separate journeys to Mars.
[Patrick] A robot is important for forerunner exploration,
where we send a robot first.
It lets us know it's OK for us to go there.
translation.ko: 우리가 거기 가도 되는지 알려 줘요

translation.en: The planet Mars right now is entirely populated by robots,
which is an interesting thing to think about.
[Bobak Ferdowsi] Curiosity's designed specifically to look at
past habitability and present habitability of Mars.
translation.ko: 현재와 과거의 주거성을 조사하기 위해 제작됐어요

translation.en: That's really taking the step of where we understood there was once water on Mars
translation.ko: 한때 화성에 물이 존재했다는 사실에서 더 나아가

translation.en: to whether that water could have supported life on Mars,
translation.ko: 이젠 그 물이 생명체를 유지할 수 있었는지

translation.en: or maybe even still support life on Mars.
translation.ko: 혹은 지금도 생명체가 있는지 확인하는 거죠

translation.en: [mission control] And liftoff of the Atlas 5 with Curiosity,
seeking clues to the planetary puzzle about life on Mars.
translation.ko: 이는 화성 생명체에 관한 행성의 수수께끼를 풀 겁니다

translation.en: [Ferdowsi] The thing that makes Mars so incredible is that it's this sister planet of ours,
translation.ko: 화성이 그토록 멋진 이유는 지구의 자매 행성이면서

translation.en: and the possibility that life could have arisen there some time in the past,
translation.ko: 과거 어느 시점에 생명체가 발생했을 수 있고

translation.en: that maybe life is more prevalent than we thought in the past.
translation.ko: 우리 생각보다 생명체가 더 흔할 수도 있기 때문이에요

translation.en: [mission control] At 10.13 local time we'll initiate the descent stage thermal batteries,
and from that point on EDL ops will take over.
[Ferdowsi] I'm a little partial to the Curiosity rover.
[mission control] We're down to 90 meters per second
at an altitude of 6.5 kilometers and descending.
I worked on that mission for almost 10 years.
[mission control] UHF is good.
Touchdown confirmed. We're safe on Mars!
[Ferdowsi] I think the longer you spend working on them, the more attached you are to them.
translation.ko: 오래 작업할수록 애착이 강해지는 것 같아요

translation.en: They become kind of like kids.
We are going to need a button pusher.
-I can do that. -Jace!
Jace, just a heads up, that's priority numero uno!
translation.ko: 제이스, 참고로 말하는데 그게 제일 중요한 거야

translation.en: Jace is a good programmer. We can't afford not to--
-Jace, are you programming right now? -Yes.
[Jace] With these robots, you have to learn
how to program them to work without a human being at the controls.
translation.ko: 사람의 통제 없이도 일하게끔 설정하는 법을 배워야 해요

translation.en: Can Bucky hold one side of the yellow doors?
translation.ko: 버키가 노란색 문 한쪽을 잡을 수 있어?

translation.en: Which side do you want? I can program for both.
translation.ko: 어느 쪽으로 할까? 양쪽 다 설정할 수 있어

translation.en: Jace is so good at programming. He just went right to it!
He's got a ton of patience when it comes to testing that robot.
translation.ko: 그 로봇을 시험할 땐 인내심이 넘쳤죠

translation.en: A lot of times in retrieval,
the things are in a very specific place every time.
translation.ko: 아주 특정한 장소에 있는 경우가 많으니

translation.en: So we can make a rough program, go out, figure out what happened wrong...
translation.ko: 프로그램을 대강 만들고 나가서 뭐가 문제인지 확인하고

translation.en: ...then just make it more and more and more and more precise
so we can perfectly execute that when the mission comes.
translation.ko: 그럼 실제 임무는 완벽히 수행할 수 있죠

translation.en: Activate COMS.
Right now I'm learning how to code in Python.
I'm new to it. I'll admit, I can't make something really complicated.
translation.ko: 솔직히 초보라서 엄청 복잡한 건 못 만들어요

translation.en: I can make a game of Pong work! That's about it.
But I'm learning.
A little nervous. It should work. I programmed it for a long time.
translation.ko: 좀 떨리는데 잘될 거예요 오랫동안 프로그래밍했거든요

translation.en: [Ferdowsi] With Curiosity, what was amazing
was that the first drill hole we drilled we found evidence of past water on Mars
translation.ko: 처음 화성 땅에 뚫은 구멍에서 과거 물의 흔적을 발견한 건데

translation.en: and that that water was kind of relatively fresh
and could have supported certain types of life as we know them on Earth.
translation.ko: 지구의 특정 생명체들을 유지할 수도 있었죠

translation.en: The next questions are really of whether life could exist on Mars.
translation.ko: 그렇다면 정말 화성에 생명체가 존재할 수 있을까요?

translation.en: Future missions can go and actually look for evidence of life.
translation.ko: 향후 임무로 실제 생명의 흔적을 찾아볼 수 있는데

translation.en: And maybe the best way to do that is with humans,
translation.ko: 어쩌면 가장 좋은 방법은 아폴로 임무처럼 인간이 표본을 갖고 돌아오는 거겠죠

translation.en: where they can bring samples back, like the Apollo missions did.
translation.ko: 아폴로 임무처럼 인간이 표본을 갖고 돌아오는 거겠죠

translation.en: [Kluger] When we put a robot on Mars and we give it a name called "Curiosity",
translation.ko: 우린 화성에 로봇을 보내면서 '호기심'이란 이름을 지었고

translation.en: and we have it send down automatic Tweets,
and we love it and we call it names like "plucky" and "tough".
[Raj] We're on the ground.
Just don't move yet! We gotta wait for Jace.
translation.ko: 아직 움직이지 마 제이스를 기다려야 해

translation.en: [all] Five, four, three, two, one!
[instructor] Begin!
[Kluger] We humanize robots because it's the next best thing.
translation.ko: 로봇을 인간화하는 건 그게 차선책이기 때문이에요

translation.en: But in the case of explorers on other planets,
humanizing, anthropomorphizing our machines
are because we don't have real people to get there.
translation.ko: 거기까지 갈 실제 인간이 없기 때문입니다

translation.en: [Raj] All right, lost a wheel.
[Ferdowsi] Humans can do in a day
what it takes a robot months or sometimes years to accomplish.
translation.ko: 로봇의 몇 달, 몇 년 치 일을 할 수 있어요

translation.en: Curiosity's been on the surface for a little more than three years now,
translation.ko: 큐리오시티가 3년 넘게 화성 표면에서 탐사한 건

translation.en: and we guess that a human could do that within a week.
translation.ko: 인간이 일주일 안에 할 수 있는 일이에요

translation.en: All the science that we've done so far in that three years,
a human could walk around, chisel rocks, look at them, investigate them.
translation.ko: 인간이 돌아다니며 돌을 깎고 조사하면 할 수 있는 거죠

translation.en: Don't move that. Don't move that. Patrick, don't move it!
translation.ko: 그거 움직이지 마 패트릭, 움직이지 마!

translation.en: Patrick, don't move it!
I can get it.
Just kind of disappointed that our bot didn't function how we wanted it to.
translation.ko: 우리 로봇이 뜻대로 작동하지 않아서 실망했어요

translation.en: It was only able to complete two or three tasks,
rather than the about six that we had planned for.
[deGrasse Tyson] I've yet to see a ticker tape parade for robots.
Or a high school named after a robot.
So, there's the vicarious value that one of us experiences that
translation.ko: 인간이 로봇 대신 경험하고 돌아와서 얘기를 전하면

translation.en: and comes back to talk about it.
You can touch that person.
And that person carried out the dreams of a civilization.
translation.ko: 그 사람은 문명의 꿈을 실행한 겁니다

translation.en: -[camper] No! -[Raj] Yo, man. Just keep going!
-[camper] Ten seconds! -[instructor] Nine, eight, seven, six...
[all] ...five, four, three, two, one...
-Zero! -[instructor] Stop all your robots!
[Jace] Programming error.
Bot didn't function properly as how it was intended to.
translation.ko: 로봇이 제 의도대로 잘 작동하지 않았어요

translation.en: It didn't perform as it did during testing.
translation.ko: 시험 단계만큼 임무를 잘 수행하지 못했죠

translation.en: It was really kind of down to me, and I kind of failed at the last second.
translation.ko: 저한테 달린 문제였는데 제가 막판에 실패했네요

translation.en: [Josh] The best thing about Mars and why everybody wants to go to Mars
translation.ko: 화성이 멋지고 다들 그곳에 가려는 이유는

translation.en: is because we have rovers there.
We have machines, examples,
everything from it that says, "Hey come, come to Mars, come to Mars."
[camper] Can this be one of our layers?
[instructor] Yeah! You can use that as one of your layers!
translation.ko: 그럼, 네 우주복에 한 겹 넣어도 돼

translation.en: [Josh] OK, we're naming it Neil Applestrong.
Applenaut training, so that's where we have an astronaut that's a green apple
translation.ko: '우주 사과' 훈련은 우주인 대신 풋사과를 위해

translation.en: and we make a space suit for it.
[Jace] A really good way to look at a space suit
is it has to keep you alive with oxygen and pressure.
translation.ko: 산소와 압력으로 사람을 살려야 한다는 거예요

translation.en: So a one-minute test.
When it comes out you're gonna blot it dry.
We'll walk over to the hot box.
Go. Down, down, down.
When it comes to space, I know a lot.
translation.ko: 저는 우주에 관해 아는 게 많아요

translation.en: [instructor] Stop! Hold them up.
Oh, no!
This is unfortunate.
-What? -[Jace] I think there's water inside.
[Josh] People living in space for a year now, that's huge for me. I love it.
translation.ko: 사람들이 1년째 우주에 산다니 정말 멋지고 굉장한 일인데

translation.en: And it's like, whoa! I want to live in space for five years now!
translation.ko: 이제 저는 5년간 우주에서 살아 보고 싶어요

translation.en: [Abby] To apply to become an astronaut,
all you have to do is go to the NASA website
and you'll find a PDF that you can download, fill out, send back in.
translation.ko: PDF 파일을 내려받아 작성하고 제출하면 돼요

translation.en: The basic requirements to be an astronaut
are not actually that difficult to achieve.
You need to have a four-year degree in a related field of STEM:
Science, Technology, Engineering, and Math.
You need to have things such as general good health,
reasonably good eyesight, hearing, those types of things.
translation.ko: 시력, 청력 등이 꽤 좋아야 하죠

translation.en: But it's when you look at the requirements that aren't stated
that things become more difficult.
[Dr. Bob Behnken] The original group of seven folks,
translation.ko: 최초 비행단 7인은 다들 군 복무 경험을 갖추고 나사에 왔습니다

translation.en: they were all military background when they came into the office.
translation.ko: 다들 군 복무 경험을 갖추고 나사에 왔습니다

translation.en: But of course the mission of actually going on to Mars
really requires a wide range of experiences,
and so that includes medical doctors, it includes scientists,
pretty much everything under the sun.
I think I get smarter as I get older!
translation.ko: 난 나이 먹으면서 더 영리해지는 것 같아

translation.en: My time here as an astronaut
and my ability to have gone to space two times
translation.ko: 우주에 두 번 다녀온 제 역량을 통해

translation.en: has helped taken some baby steps
to take that next generation of space explorers even further.
translation.ko: 더 멀리 나아갈 수 있는 기틀을 제공한 것 같아요

translation.en: [Dr. Thomas] I'm way too old to go to Mars.
translation.ko: 저는 너무 늙어서 화성에 못 갑니다

translation.en: 25, 30 years from now, I'm gonna be 85, 90 years-old.
No way is NASA sending me to Mars.
[Dr. Kaku] The Mars Generation, is the generation of today.
It's in their DNA to become the astronauts, to explore the red planet.
translation.ko: 그들은 붉은 행성을 탐사할 우주인이 될 운명이에요

translation.en: [Abby] Ever since I was a little kid, I've wanted to be an astronaut.
translation.ko: 저는 어릴 때부터 우주인이 되고 싶었어요

translation.en: Going to Mars is definitely something that would help NASA to draw public interest
translation.ko: 화성에 간다면 확실히 나사가 대중의 관심을 끌고

translation.en: and to reignite that fire we have for space travel.
translation.ko: 우주여행을 향한 열망을 되살릴 수 있겠죠

translation.en: [Ian] We were born at exactly the right time.
We will be in our early 30s around the time we are predicted to set foot on Mars.
And Neil Armstrong was only 38 when he set foot on the Moon.
translation.ko: 닐 암스트롱은 달을 밟았을 때 겨우 38세였죠

translation.en: [Alyssa] The age you should really start focusing more
and becoming really serious about becoming an astronaut
is for me, would probably be now,
so around 14.
Mainly because I'm starting to get
those certifications that I'll need in the future,
such as SCUBA diving certification, pilot's license
and sky diving certification.
[Rachel] When I got into space heavily, I was probably about 13.

translation.en: [Urban] What we're talking about eventually
is a blue-green planet with maybe 7 billion of its own people on it.
translation.ko: 70억 명이 거주하는 청록색 행성이 될 수도 있어요

translation.en: And you could look at a picture of a gorgeous green mountain
and a lake and not know what planet you're looking at.
translation.ko: 그게 어느 행성인지 모를 수도 있죠

translation.en: [deGrasse Tyson] It's a brand new planet, who knows what future economies await us
translation.ko: 새로운 행성 표면에서 어떤 미래 경제가 기다릴지

translation.en: on that planetary surface?
Even if you can't think of one now, it doesn't mean there isn't one.
translation.ko: 지금 상상할 수 없다고 해서 불가능한 건 아니죠

translation.en: And especially given the history of exploration and discovery,
translation.ko: 특히 탐험과 발견의 역사를 볼 때

translation.en: there probably will be.
[Kluger] When you go somewhere else and live in a wild, rustic life,
translation.ko: 다른 행성으로 떠나 야생에서 소박하게 산다면

translation.en: you've made the decision that that kind of life,
the world you're building,
is more valuable to you than the world that's already built.
translation.ko: 이미 확립된 세계보다 더 중요하다고 판단한 겁니다

translation.en: Your motivation is to live here, to settle here, to die here.
translation.ko: 화성에 살고, 정착하고 그곳에서 죽고자 하는 거죠

translation.en: Because what you have in mind
is three, five, a hundred generations beyond you,
and you've made the decision that you're going to be
translation.ko: 당신은 그 새로운 세상의 땅에 박힐

translation.en: the first stake in the ground of that new world.
translation.ko: 첫 번째 말뚝이 되기로 결정한 거니까요

translation.en: [Jace] Tell Orion that you're gonna start their primary ingress checklist
translation.ko: 오리온의 선장, 조종사와 DDP, B1, B2에게

translation.en: for Commander and Pilot and DDP 1 and 2 and B 1 and 2.
[Colin] All right, so...you first, Orion, on F1.
Primary ingress checklist for Pilot and Commander...
All right, IDP CR22 power is on.
Major functions set to DNC.
We ordered that pizza 45 minutes ago. It's been over 30 minutes. It's free now.
translation.ko: 45분 전에 피자 주문했는데 30분 지났으니 이제 공짜야

translation.en: No it's not. They stopped doing that anyway.
[Patrick] I want my free pizza!
-[Raj] All checklists are done. -Yay! Ascent procedures.
translation.ko: - 점검표 확인 완료 - 좋아, 상승 절차다

translation.en: [Raj] Everyone switch to ascent procedures.
[all] Five, four, three, two, one...
[camper] Oh my goodness! That is amazing.
[Dr. Thomas] One thing that's impressed me the most, of anything else,
translation.ko: 제가 가장 감동한 것 중 하나는

translation.en: is that kids today have that same drive,
translation.ko: 제가 어릴 적 미국의 첫 번째 우주선 발사를 지켜보며

translation.en: that same interest, that same passion for space exploration
translation.ko: 우주 탐험에 관해 품었던 그 투지, 흥미와 열정을

translation.en: that I had as a young boy watching the first American launch into space.
translation.ko: 오늘날 아이들도 똑같이 품고 있다는 겁니다

translation.en: -[camper] That's a lot of retro. -[Raj] All right, listen up Orion.
Now we're done with launch so start focusing on our checklist again.
translation.ko: 이제 발사가 끝났으니 다시 점검표에 집중하라

translation.en: Our engines are turned off. We are good to unbuckle.
I'm floating around in the most peculiar way.
Early this morning, the Space Launch System launched from Cape Canaveral,
translation.ko: 오늘 오전 케이프 커내버럴에서 우주 발사 체계를 발사했고

translation.en: carrying along with it the Orion capsule and six brave Americans
on their way to go boldly where no man has ever gone before.
translation.ko: 인류가 처음 개척하는 길로 과감히 출발했습니다

translation.en: Let's do this!
[Kluger] Exploration is absolutely embedded in our DNA.
translation.ko: 확실히 탐험 정신은 우리 DNA 안에 있어요

translation.en: If we are on this hill, we want to know what's on the next hill.
translation.ko: 우린 이 언덕에 서서 다음 언덕을 궁금해하죠

translation.en: We cannot help ourselves.
There's no reason for us not to surrender to that impulse.
translation.ko: 그 충동에 굴복하지 않을 이유가 없어요

translation.en: [Ferdowsi] The first steps on Mars won't just be a national moment of pride,
translation.ko: 화성에 내디딜 첫걸음은 한 국가의 자부심이 아닌

translation.en: but really a worldwide moment of pride,
translation.ko: 전 세계가 자부심을 느낄 순간이 될 테고

translation.en: and ultimately, I think, kicks off this sense of exploration on the right foot,
translation.ko: 결국에는 이런 탐험 정신의 첫 단추를 잘 끼워서

translation.en: of one that is as an entirely global experience.
translation.ko: 전 세계가 그 경험을 함께하게 되겠죠

translation.en: [deGrasse Tyson] I have good evidence that space matters to the hearts and minds of people.
translation.ko: 인간에게 우주가 중요하다는 좋은 증거가 있습니다

translation.en: There's something special, I think, about the night sky
and about the universe
that lives within us.
[Nye] There are two questions that get everybody.
translation.ko: 모두가 공감하는 두 가지 질문이 있는데

translation.en: The first one is: where did we come from?
translation.ko: 첫 번째 질문은 우린 어디에서 왔을까요?

translation.en: Where did we all come from? How did we get here?
And the other question is: are we alone in the universe?
translation.ko: 그리고 두 번째 질문은 우주에는 우리뿐일까요?

translation.en: If we were to discover evidence of life,
or stranger still, something alive on Mars today,
translation.ko: 생명의 증거나 살아 있는 이방인을 발견하면

translation.en: it would change the course of human history
in the same way astronomy has humbled us in the past.
translation.ko: 과거 천문학이 우리를 겸손하게 한 것처럼요

translation.en: The Earth is not flat.
We are not the center of it. The Sun's the center of it.
Wait! The Sun's not the center of it.
We're just one more sun in this galactic disc.
translation.ko: 우린 그저 이 은하계의 또 다른 태양계일 뿐이고

translation.en: And we're not the only galaxy! We're not by any means!
We're just these specks on a speck orbiting specks in specklessness.
translation.ko: 우린 그저 수많은 점 중 하나에 불과하고

translation.en: We're nothing.
Yet, we can understand that.
translation.ko: 다만 우리는 그 사실을 이해할 수 있죠

translation.en: [Urban] Humans have lived a thousand centuries so far.
This century is the first time where suddenly going to Mars is an option.
translation.ko: 문득 이번 세기에 처음으로 화성에 가는 게 가능해졌어요

translation.en: [deGrasse Tyson] I think it's awesome that we have an entire generation of people
translation.ko: 하나의 세대 전체가 우주와 화성에 가고자 하고

translation.en: who want to go to into space, who want to go Mars,
who want to be STEM fluent.
But I can tell you that all of that will fall on fallow soil,
translation.ko: 하지만 그 모든 게 허사가 될지도 모릅니다

translation.en: if there isn't some big mission
on the other side of that educational pipeline
translation.ko: 이 에너지와 열정을 쏟아부을 수 있는

translation.en: where they can apply this energy and this enthusiasm.
[Dr. Kaku] It's our duty to breathe life and fire into the imagination of these young people
translation.ko: 이 청년들의 상상력에 생기를 불어넣는 게 우리 의무예요

translation.en: so they will say, "Yes! I want to become an astronaut!
translation.ko: 그들은 이렇게 말하겠죠 '그래, 난 우주인이 될래'

translation.en: I want to explore outer space!"
Because our true place is among the stars.
[Colin] Oh wow, we're landing.
We're landing. Guys, we're landing.
We are frickin' landing on Mars right now.
Dude, dude, dude. We just landed.
We're on Mars.
[Abby] I hope that my generation will be defined by Mars.
I can't think of a better thing to be defined by!
translation.ko: 그보다 더 좋은 정의는 없을 것 같네요

translation.en: [Jace] Somebody from my generation will step out of the lander
translation.ko: 우리 세대 중 누군가가 착륙선에서 나와

translation.en: and put their footprint down in the Martian soil.
If I could contribute to that in any way, it would be an amazing experience.
translation.ko: 제가 뭐든 기여할 수 있다면 멋진 경험이 될 거예요

translation.en: [Rachel] This date will go down in history.
After a long 183-day journey,
six Americans have finally exited the all-terra lander
and put their boots in the red Martian soil.
The Mars Generation is...us.
[Jace] Exploration is ingrained within our DNA.
translation.ko: 우린 DNA 속에 탐험 정신을 타고났어요

translation.en: Human beings, they want to learn about the cosmos.
[Josh] We know so little about space.
There's so much to do and so much to learn.
translation.ko: 할 일도 많고 배울 것도 많은데

translation.en: And I want to do it all.
[Aurora] Like, can you imagine if there was just nothing else?
translation.ko: 우주에 아무것도 없다면 어떨 것 같으세요?

translation.en: That we had found everything there is to find?
translation.ko: 이미 세상 모든 이치를 발견한 거라면

translation.en: Life would be so boring!
Let's go. Let's go to Mars.
[Raj] It's been long enough.
We need to go for it, full speed.
Because humans need to do significant things,
translation.ko: 인간은 의미 있는 일을 해야 하잖아요

translation.en: because that's just how humanity is.
We gotta get off this planet and we gotta land on Mars.
translation.ko: 이 행성을 떠나서 화성에 착륙해야 해요
